title: Song of Solomon Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Song of Solomon chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Song of Solomon Chapter 5.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:1, what has the speaker gathered in her garden?
questions.correctAnswer: Myrrh with my spice
questions.explanation: The speaker says, 'I have gathered my myrrh with my spice' as stated in Song of Solomon 5:1.

questions.question: Who is knocking and asking to be let in according to Song of Solomon 5:2?
questions.correctAnswer: My beloved
questions.explanation: Verse 5:2 says, 'it is the voice of my beloved that knocketh, saying, Open to me.'

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 5:3, what has the speaker put off and does not want to put on again?
questions.correctAnswer: Her coat
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'I have put off my coat; how shall I put it on?'

questions.question: What was the speaker's physical reaction when her beloved put his hand by the hole of the door in Song of Solomon 5:4?
options: Her bowels were moved for him
questions.correctAnswer: Her bowels were moved for him
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 5:4 says, 'my bowels were moved for him' when he put in his hand by the hole of the door.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:5, what did the speaker's hands drop with when she rose to open the door?
questions.correctAnswer: Myrrh
questions.explanation: Verse 5 says, 'my hands dropped with myrrh, and my fingers with sweet smelling myrrh.'

questions.question: What happened when the speaker opened the door to her beloved as described in Song of Solomon 5:6?
options: He had withdrawn and was gone
questions.correctAnswer: He had withdrawn and was gone
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'I opened to my beloved; but my beloved had withdrawn himself, and was gone.'

questions.question: Who found the speaker and wounded her according to Song of Solomon 5:7?
questions.correctAnswer: The watchmen
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states, 'The watchmen that went about the city found me, they smote me, they wounded me.'

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:8, to whom does the speaker charge to tell if they find her beloved?
questions.correctAnswer: The daughters of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: The speaker says, 'I charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if ye find my beloved, that ye tell him.'

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 5:10, how is the beloved described?
questions.correctAnswer: White and ruddy
questions.explanation: Verse 10 describes the beloved as 'white and ruddy, the chiefest among ten thousand.'

questions.question: What color are the beloved's eyes described as in Song of Solomon 5:12?
questions.correctAnswer: As the eyes of doves
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states, 'His eyes are as the eyes of doves by the rivers of waters.'

questions.question: True or False: In Song of Solomon 5:13, the beloved's lips are compared to lilies dropping sweet smelling myrrh.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse reads, 'his lips like lilies, dropping sweet smelling myrrh.'

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 5:7 records that the keepers of the walls took away the speaker's veil.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 7 says, 'the keepers of the walls took away my veil from me.'

questions.question: True or False: The speaker calls her beloved 'my friend' in Song of Solomon 5:16.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'This is my beloved, and this is my friend.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Song of Solomon 5:14: 'His hands are as gold rings set with the ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: beryl
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'His hands are as gold rings set with the beryl.'

questions.question: Complete the description from Song of Solomon 5:15: 'His legs are as pillars of marble, set upon sockets of ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: fine gold
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states, 'His legs are as pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold.'

medium.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Song of Solomon Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 5:2 teach us about faith and trust during times when God’s voice seems distant or silent?
options: Trust that God is always present even when we don't immediately respond
Ignore the voice until you feel ready
Doubt the voice if it causes fear
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God is always present even when we don't immediately respond
questions.explanation: Verse 2 shows the beloved knocking and calling, signifying God's persistent presence and desire for relationship even if we feel asleep or distant. Trusting that God is near helps us respond in faith (Song of Solomon 5:2, 5:6, 5:8).

questions.question: A believer struggles with hesitation in obedience. Based on Song of Solomon 5:3, what biblical truth would encourage them to act with purity and readiness?
options: Purity prepares us to respond to God’s call
questions.correctAnswer: Purity prepares us to respond to God’s call
questions.explanation: The speaker puts off her coat and washes her feet, symbolizing preparation and purity before opening to the beloved, teaching the value of spiritual readiness and holiness before God (Song of Solomon 5:3, 5:4, 5:5).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 5:6 encourage perseverance when feeling abandoned or unanswered in prayer?
options: Continue seeking God even when answers seem delayed
Stop praying if no immediate response
Seek human help instead of God
questions.correctAnswer: Continue seeking God even when answers seem delayed
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows the beloved withdrawing, and the speaker’s soul failing, yet she continues to seek and call out, illustrating the call to persevere in prayer and faith despite apparent silence (Song of Solomon 5:6, 5:8, 5:2).

questions.question: What lesson about forgiveness and reconciliation can be drawn from the watchmen's treatment of the speaker in Song of Solomon 5:7?
options: Endure trials with grace and seek restoration
Retaliate against those who harm us
Avoid all confrontation at any cost
questions.correctAnswer: Endure trials with grace and seek restoration
questions.explanation: The watchmen harm the speaker, yet the text invites reflection on enduring hardship and seeking reconciliation rather than retaliation, applicable to forgiving those who wound us (Song of Solomon 5:7, 5:8, 5:6).

questions.question: How does the speaker’s charge in Song of Solomon 5:8 teach about evangelism and sharing the love of Christ with others?
options: Boldly share the message of love even when vulnerable
Only share faith with close family
questions.correctAnswer: Boldly share the message of love even when vulnerable
questions.explanation: The speaker asks the daughters of Jerusalem to tell her beloved she is sick of love, showing openness and boldness in sharing heartfelt spiritual truths, encouraging believers to be open witnesses (Song of Solomon 5:8, 5:6, 5:2).

questions.question: Based on Song of Solomon 5:10-16, how can the depiction of the beloved inspire believers in their personal devotion and reverence for Christ?
options: Appreciate Christ’s perfection and beauty, inspiring worship
Ignore Christ’s attributes in daily life
questions.correctAnswer: Appreciate Christ’s perfection and beauty, inspiring worship
questions.explanation: Verses 10-16 describe the beloved’s beauty and excellence, symbolizing Christ’s perfect nature and encouraging believers to deepen personal devotion and reverence in worship (Song of Solomon 5:10-16).

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 5 teaches that spiritual intimacy requires active participation and openness.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The speaker actively opens the door to the beloved (5:5-6), demonstrating that spiritual intimacy involves willing openness and participation (Song of Solomon 5:3-6).

questions.question: True or False: The speaker in Song of Solomon 5 immediately finds her beloved when she opens the door.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 6 clearly states the beloved had withdrawn and was gone when she opened the door, teaching that sometimes God’s timing differs from our expectations (Song of Solomon 5:6).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Song of Solomon 5:1, the speaker invites her friends and beloved to eat and drink _____ and abundantly.
questions.correctAnswer: abundantly
questions.explanation: Verse 1 invites friends and beloved to eat and drink abundantly, symbolizing generosity and joy in fellowship and spiritual nourishment (Song of Solomon 5:1).

questions.question: How can Song of Solomon 5:4 teach us about sincere emotional responses in relationships and marriage?
options: True love moves the heart deeply and genuinely
Emotions should be hidden to maintain control
Only rational thoughts matter in love
questions.correctAnswer: True love moves the heart deeply and genuinely
questions.explanation: The beloved putting his hand through the door moves the speaker’s bowels (emotions), teaching that sincere love involves deep emotional engagement (Song of Solomon 5:4, 5:5).

questions.question: What does the imagery of the beloved’s eyes being "as the eyes of doves by the rivers of waters, washed with milk" in Song of Solomon 5:12 teach about spiritual purity and gentleness?
options: Spiritual purity and gentleness are beautiful and essential
Gentleness is a weakness in faith
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual purity and gentleness are beautiful and essential
questions.explanation: The dove’s eyes washed with milk symbolize purity and gentle love, encouraging believers to cultivate these virtues in daily life (Song of Solomon 5:12, 5:3).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 5:13 encourage believers to appreciate God’s blessings and express gratitude?
options: Recognize the sweetness and fragrance of God’s gifts with thankfulness
Focus only on spiritual discipline without joy
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize the sweetness and fragrance of God’s gifts with thankfulness
questions.explanation: The cheeks as a bed of spices and lips like lilies dropping sweet myrrh symbolize the richness of God’s blessings, encouraging gratitude and joyful appreciation (Song of Solomon 5:13, 5:1).

questions.question: Based on Song of Solomon 5:15, how can believers learn about stability and strength in their spiritual walk?
options: Like legs of marble set on gold sockets, faith should be strong and grounded
Spiritual walk should be flexible and unstable
Avoid standing firm to prevent conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Like legs of marble set on gold sockets, faith should be strong and grounded
questions.explanation: The imagery of strong pillars set on fine gold symbolizes a stable and valuable foundation, teaching believers to build a strong, unwavering faith (Song of Solomon 5:15, 5:10).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 5:16 emphasize the importance of love and friendship in Christian fellowship?
options: Love and friendship are inseparable and enhance spiritual community
Friendship is less important than ritual
Love should be hidden from the church
questions.correctAnswer: Love and friendship are inseparable and enhance spiritual community
questions.explanation: Verse 16 calls the beloved both lovely and friend, emphasizing that affectionate love and friendship are foundational in the Christian community (Song of Solomon 5:16, 5:8).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to doubt God’s goodness due to unanswered prayers. What truth from Song of Solomon 5:6 and 5:8 would you share to encourage perseverance?
options: God’s love remains steadfast even when silent
Prayer is only effective if immediately answered
questions.correctAnswer: God’s love remains steadfast even when silent
questions.explanation: Verses 5:6 and 5:8 show the beloved’s withdrawal and the speaker’s longing, yet the call to continue seeking and sharing love teaches that God’s love is constant even when answers seem delayed (Song of Solomon 5:6, 5:8).

hard.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Song of Solomon Chapter 5.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:1, the speaker invites friends and beloved to partake in what items gathered from the garden?
questions.correctAnswer: Myrrh and honeycomb
questions.explanation: Verse 1 mentions gathering myrrh with spice and eating honeycomb with honey, inviting friends and beloved to eat and drink abundantly.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:2, the beloved's voice is described as knocking and requesting what specific action?
questions.correctAnswer: Open to me
questions.explanation: The beloved knocks saying, 'Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled,' asking to be allowed in.

questions.question: What is the significance of the speaker saying 'I have put off my coat; how shall I put it on?' in Song of Solomon 5:3 in the context of ancient Near Eastern hospitality?
options: It symbolizes vulnerability and hesitation to re-enter the world
It signifies mourning for the beloved
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes vulnerability and hesitation to re-enter the world
questions.explanation: Removing coat and washing feet (v.3) indicate preparation for intimacy and purity; hesitance to put them back on shows vulnerability after the beloved's departure.

questions.question: The phrase 'my bowels were moved for him' in Song of Solomon 5:4 is best understood as an expression of:
questions.correctAnswer: Deep emotional longing
questions.explanation: In Hebrew idiom, 'bowels' signify inner feelings or compassion, indicating intense emotional stirring for the beloved.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:6, what is the emotional response of the speaker when the beloved withdraws?
options: Soul failed, sought him but could not find him
questions.correctAnswer: Soul failed, sought him but could not find him
questions.explanation: Verse 6 describes the beloved withdrawing, causing the speaker's soul to fail and a fruitless search for him.

questions.question: Who are the ones that find, smite, and wound the speaker in Song of Solomon 5:7, and what might they symbolize in the historical context?
options: Watchmen of the city, symbolizing societal judgment or opposition
questions.correctAnswer: Watchmen of the city, symbolizing societal judgment or opposition
questions.explanation: Watchmen and keepers who wound and remove the veil represent external societal forces opposing or judging the speaker.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:8, the speaker charges the daughters of Jerusalem to do what if they find her beloved?
options: Tell him she is sick of love
Ask him to leave her alone
questions.correctAnswer: Tell him she is sick of love
questions.explanation: The speaker explicitly charges the daughters of Jerusalem to inform the beloved that she is overwhelmed and sick with love.

questions.question: The description of the beloved's head as 'the most fine gold' and his locks 'black as a raven' in Song of Solomon 5:11 uses which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The passage employs similes comparing the beloved's head to fine gold and hair to a raven's black feathers.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the beloved's eyes in Song of Solomon 5:12 ('eyes of doves by the rivers of waters, washed with milk') connect to biblical symbolism of purity and peace?
options: Doves symbolize innocence and eyes washed with milk indicate purity
Doves represent war and milk represents nourishment
Eyes of doves symbolize vigilance and rivers symbolize chaos
It is a literal description without symbolism
questions.correctAnswer: Doves symbolize innocence and eyes washed with milk indicate purity
questions.explanation: Doves are biblical symbols of peace and innocence; washing with milk symbolizes cleansing and purity, enhancing the beloved's gentle character.

questions.question: The depiction of the beloved's cheeks as 'a bed of spices' and lips 'like lilies' in Song of Solomon 5:13 reflects what kind of literary motif common in ancient Near Eastern love poetry?
options: Sensory imagery to evoke beauty and desirability
questions.correctAnswer: Sensory imagery to evoke beauty and desirability
questions.explanation: The use of spices and flowers appeals to the senses, a common motif in love poetry emphasizing attractiveness and allure.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:14, what does the description of the beloved's belly as 'bright ivory overlaid with sapphires' symbolize in the cultural context of the ancient Near East?
questions.correctAnswer: Nobility and preciousness
questions.explanation: Ivory and sapphires were luxury materials symbolizing wealth, nobility, and high status, elevating the beloved's stature.

questions.question: The comparison of the beloved's legs to 'pillars of marble' set upon sockets of fine gold in Song of Solomon 5:15 is an example of what architectural metaphor, and what might it signify about his character?
questions.correctAnswer: Strength and stability
questions.explanation: Pillars symbolize strength and support; marble and gold denote beauty and value, indicating the beloved's noble and steadfast character.

questions.question: The final verse (Song of Solomon 5:16) calls the beloved 'altogether lovely' and 'my friend.' How does this dual title contribute to the theological understanding of love in the biblical tradition?
options: It emphasizes both romantic and covenantal friendship
It limits love to physical attraction only
It introduces conflict between love and friendship
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes both romantic and covenantal friendship
questions.explanation: Calling the beloved both lovely and friend integrates romantic love with deep covenantal friendship, reflecting biblical intimacy's multifaceted nature.

questions.question: True or False: In Song of Solomon 5:7, the watchmen and keepers of the walls are portrayed as protectors who help the speaker find her beloved safely.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 7 describes the watchmen as those who smote, wounded, and took away the speaker's veil, indicating opposition rather than protection.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the overall literary structure of Song of Solomon 5 as seen in the provided text?
options: A lament followed by an encomium
questions.correctAnswer: A lament followed by an encomium
questions.explanation: The chapter begins with lament over separation (vv.2-8) and transitions to a laudatory description of the beloved's beauty (vv.9-16), fitting lament and encomium structure.

theological.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Song of Solomon Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:2, the beloved's voice is described as knocking. What theological theme does this imagery most closely represent?
options: The persistent call of Christ to the soul
The silence of God in human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: The persistent call of Christ to the soul
questions.explanation: The beloved knocking and calling to 'Open to me' (Song of Solomon 5:2) parallels Christ's call in Revelation 3:20 to 'open the door,' symbolizing the persistent invitation of Christ to believers. This imagery aligns with God's patient calling in Isaiah 55:6 and the Father's longing for sinners in Luke 15:20, emphasizing salvation and relational intimacy.

questions.question: Which attribute of the beloved is emphasized by the description 'His head is as the most fine gold' in Song of Solomon 5:11?
questions.correctAnswer: His purity and divine glory
questions.explanation: Gold in Scripture often symbolizes purity and divine glory (Exodus 28:36; Psalm 19:10). The description in Song of Solomon 5:11 reflects the beloved's exalted and glorious nature, which resonates with Christ's divine majesty seen in Revelation 1:14 and 1 Peter 1:19.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:6, the beloved withdraws after the speaker opens the door. What doctrinal truth can be drawn from this interaction?
options: The experience of divine hiddenness and human longing for God
The inevitability of eternal separation from God
The rejection of grace by the believer
questions.correctAnswer: The experience of divine hiddenness and human longing for God
questions.explanation: The beloved's withdrawal after the door is opened (Song 5:6) illustrates the tension in the believer's experience of God's presence and absence, akin to the 'dark night of the soul' (Psalm 42:1-3; Isaiah 49:14-16). This underscores the theological reality of God's hiddenness while maintaining relational intimacy, as seen also in Habakkuk 3:17-18 and 2 Corinthians 12:7-10.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 5:10, the beloved is described as 'chiefest among ten thousand.' What does this superlative indicate about Christ's uniqueness?
options: His supremacy over all creation and beings
questions.correctAnswer: His supremacy over all creation and beings
questions.explanation: The phrase 'chiefest among ten thousand' (Song 5:10) signifies Christ’s incomparable superiority, reflecting biblical affirmations of His preeminence (Colossians 1:15-18; Hebrews 1:3) and exalted status above all principalities (Ephesians 1:20-22). This highlights His unique role as the sovereign Lord.

questions.question: What does the imagery of the beloved's eyes being 'as the eyes of doves' in Song of Solomon 5:12 symbolize in a Christological context?
options: Purity, gentleness, and the Holy Spirit's peace
questions.correctAnswer: Purity, gentleness, and the Holy Spirit's peace
questions.explanation: Doves symbolize purity, innocence, and peace in Scripture (Matthew 3:16; Psalm 68:13). The beloved's eyes 'as doves' (Song 5:12) evoke Christ’s gentle and pure nature and the peace He brings, consistent with John 14:27 and Galatians 5:22. This symbolizes His compassionate and peaceful gaze upon His people.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:8, the speaker charges the daughters of Jerusalem regarding her beloved. Theologically, what does this represent about the community's role in the believer's spiritual journey?
options: The intercessory and supportive role of the faith community
The judgmental nature of the church
questions.correctAnswer: The intercessory and supportive role of the faith community
questions.explanation: The speaker’s charge to the daughters of Jerusalem to seek her beloved (Song 5:8) illustrates the communal dimension of faith, emphasizing mutual support and intercession found in Hebrews 10:24-25 and 1 Timothy 2:1. It highlights the church's role in encouraging and restoring believers.

questions.question: How does the description of the beloved's legs as 'pillars of marble' in Song of Solomon 5:15 reflect a theological truth about Christ?
options: His strength, stability, and foundational role in salvation
questions.correctAnswer: His strength, stability, and foundational role in salvation
questions.explanation: Pillars symbolize strength and foundation in Scripture (Exodus 17:12; 1 Timothy 3:15). The beloved's legs as 'pillars of marble' (Song 5:15) represent Christ’s unshakable strength and His role as the foundation of the Church (1 Corinthians 3:11; Ephesians 2:20). This imagery conveys His eternal and stable nature.

questions.question: Song of Solomon 5:5 mentions the speaker’s hands dropping with myrrh upon the lock. What doctrinal significance can be drawn from this fragrant myrrh in relation to Christ?
options: The sacrificial and redemptive work of Christ
questions.correctAnswer: The sacrificial and redemptive work of Christ
questions.explanation: Myrrh was used in burial and as a perfume in the Old Testament (John 19:39; Exodus 30:23). The myrrh on the hands (Song 5:5) symbolizes Christ’s atoning sacrifice and the sweet aroma of redemption, consistent with Hebrews 9:14 and 2 Corinthians 2:15, which describe Christ’s sacrifice as fragrant before God.

questions.question: What is the significance of the beloved being called 'my friend' in Song of Solomon 5:16 in the context of Christian doctrine?
options: The intimate and covenantal relationship between Christ and the believer
A purely human friendship without spiritual meaning
questions.correctAnswer: The intimate and covenantal relationship between Christ and the believer
questions.explanation: The term 'my friend' (Song 5:16) reflects the covenantal intimacy between Christ and His people, paralleling John 15:15 where Jesus calls His disciples friends. This signifies grace-based fellowship (Romans 5:1) and the believer's adoption as God's child (Galatians 4:7).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:7, the speaker is wounded by watchmen and has her veil taken. What theological theme could this represent?
options: The suffering and persecution experienced by the believer
The triumph of sin over salvation
questions.correctAnswer: The suffering and persecution experienced by the believer
questions.explanation: The speaker's wounds and loss of veil (Song 5:7) symbolize the trials and persecution believers may endure (2 Timothy 3:12; 1 Peter 4:12-13). The veil can represent purity or protection lost, but God’s sustaining grace is found in Psalm 34:19 and Romans 8:35-39 despite suffering.

questions.question: Which Christological attribute is highlighted by the description of the beloved’s mouth as 'most sweet' in Song of Solomon 5:16?
options: The gracious and life-giving nature of Christ’s words
questions.correctAnswer: The gracious and life-giving nature of Christ’s words
questions.explanation: The 'most sweet' mouth (Song 5:16) portrays Christ’s gracious speech that brings life and healing, as in Proverbs 16:24 and John 6:63. Jesus’ words are described as spirit and life (John 6:63), emphasizing His role as the living Word (John 1:1-4).

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 5:3, the speaker hesitates to put on her coat again or defile her feet after washing. What theological symbolism can be drawn from this?
options: The believer’s struggle with purity and the fear of defilement after sanctification
questions.correctAnswer: The believer’s struggle with purity and the fear of defilement after sanctification
questions.explanation: The hesitation to clothe and defile (Song 5:3) symbolizes the believer’s awareness of spiritual purity and the ongoing struggle against defilement (James 1:27; 1 Corinthians 6:18-20). This reflects sanctification and the desire to remain holy before God (1 Thessalonians 4:7).

questions.question: What does the imagery of the beloved’s cheeks 'as a bed of spices' and lips 'like lilies' in Song of Solomon 5:13 reveal about Christ’s character?
options: His beauty, sweetness, and aromatic presence that delights the soul
questions.correctAnswer: His beauty, sweetness, and aromatic presence that delights the soul
questions.explanation: The fragrant spices and lilies (Song 5:13) symbolize Christ’s delightful and attractive character (Psalm 45:8; Ezekiel 27:22). This aligns with the New Testament portrayal of Christ as the One who satisfies the soul’s deepest longings (John 4:14; Revelation 22:2).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 5:1, the speaker invites friends and the beloved to eat and drink abundantly. What does this invitation symbolize in Christian theology?
options: The invitation to partake of the blessings of salvation and communion with Christ
A ritualistic feast without spiritual meaning
questions.correctAnswer: The invitation to partake of the blessings of salvation and communion with Christ
questions.explanation: The invitation to eat and drink abundantly (Song 5:1) symbolizes the spiritual nourishment and blessings available in Christ (John 6:35; Isaiah 55:1-2). It reflects the joyful participation in God’s covenant, as seen in the Lord’s Supper (1 Corinthians 11:23-26) and the Messianic banquet (Revelation 19:9).

questions.question: The beloved’s hands are described as 'gold rings set with the beryl' in Song of Solomon 5:14. What doctrinal truth is conveyed by this precious imagery?
options: The preciousness and value of Christ’s works and power
questions.correctAnswer: The preciousness and value of Christ’s works and power
questions.explanation: Gold rings set with precious stones (Song 5:14) symbolize Christ’s divine authority and the preciousness of His deeds (Exodus 28:17-20; Revelation 21:18-21). This imagery reflects His sovereign power and the beauty of His righteousness (Psalm 45:9).
